docs.snippet: I have never liked flavored coffees, with their chemically enhanced effluvia of nuts, fruits or spices. But I was intrigued when I heard about Chocatal, a new coffee from Jeremiah's Pick, a San Francisco company. Mixed with the roasted coffee bean...
docs.abstract: Chocatel, chocolate-flavored coffee, is introduced by Jeremiah's Pick; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: I have never liked flavored coffees, with their chemically enhanced effluvia of nuts, fruits or spices. But I was intrigued when I heard about Chocatal, a new coffee from Jeremiah's Pick, a San Francisco company. Mixed with the roasted coffee beans are roasted cacao nibs, the small kernels that chocolate-makers pulverize to produce cocoa and chocolate. I ground some Chocatal and made what turned out to be an excellent cup of coffee. It did not taste particularly of chocolate, but it had an uncommon richness and a velvety finish. When I added cream and sugar, an engaging hint of chocolate flavor blossomed.

headline.main: Just the Thing for the Chococoffeeholic

docs.snippet: It's no ordinary basket-toting plump little Easter bunny. This is a rabbit of substance, bounding across a field as chocolatey as he is.    Suitable as the centerpiece of a holiday table, the 18-inch two-pound rabbit, above, is $40 from Jacques To...
docs.abstract: Comment on chocolate Easter bunnies and other candy items for Easter; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: It's no ordinary basket-toting plump little Easter bunny. This is a rabbit of substance, bounding across a field as chocolatey as he is. Suitable as the centerpiece of a holiday table, the 18-inch two-pound rabbit, above, is $40 from Jacques Torres Chocolate, 66 Water Street (Main Street) in Brooklyn. The shop will be open on Easter, but it is wise to call about availability: (718) 875-9772. It's a good thing that the rabbit has no time for carrots, because the one at right, from Lindt Chocolate, 692 Fifth Avenue (55th Street), is for humans only. It is made of shimmery organza and filled with foil-wrapped Easter eggs made of chocolate (milk, dark and white); $5.95.

headline.main: A Rabbit That Hops From Here Till Sunday

docs.snippet: That excellent combination, ham and Champagne, has inspired Steven Schonwetter, the owner of Bilinski's, a ham and sausage company in Cohoes, N.Y., near Albany.    There is a distinctive Champagne aroma in his new hams for the Easter season. That ...
docs.abstract: Bilinski's, ham and sausage company in Cohoes, NY, is offering champagne-marinated hams; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: That excellent combination, ham and Champagne, has inspired Steven Schonwetter, the owner of Bilinski's, a ham and sausage company in Cohoes, N.Y., near Albany. There is a distinctive Champagne aroma in his new hams for the Easter season. That is because they have been marinated for three days in Glenora Brut Champenoise, a sparkling wine from the Finger Lakes region of New York.

headline.main: For Easter Dinner, A Ham Steeped In Sparkling Wine

headline.main: If Life Hands You Lemons, Get a Good-Looking Juicer

docs.snippet: They are green and a little confused. They're identified as Persian cucumbers, but the ones being sold in New York are actually grown in Israel, Mexico and California. They resemble a seedless English cucumber, and are comparable in size to a medi...
docs.abstract: Persian cucumbers grown in Israel, Mexico and California are now available in New York; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: They are green and a little confused. They're identified as Persian cucumbers, but the ones being sold in New York are actually grown in Israel, Mexico and California. They resemble a seedless English cucumber, and are comparable in size to a medium zucchini -- but are more deeply ridged, like a Chinese bitter melon. Other small cucumbers, including the Japanese, are related to them. The texture of the Persian cucumber is meatier than a regular cucumber's, with tiny seeds and a flavor that has a hint of muskiness. Forget peeling: too much of the flesh would be lost. But sliced transparently thin, it is lovely in a salad. In slightly thicker slices, it is delicious sautéed in butter with shallots, ginger and chopped parsley. For a more elegant side dish, a little heavy cream can be added to the pan: simmer the sautéed cucumbers in it until the cream thickens and coats the slices.

headline.main: A Thin-Skinned Cucumber With Identity Issues

docs.snippet: In Japan it is called a long onion, naganegi or just negi. To an American, it looks like a scallion that is ready to play in the N.B.A.     It is nearly two feet long and is actually an Asian leek (Allium ramosum). Only the white part is used, and...
docs.abstract: Comment on Negi, Asian leek grown in California; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: In Japan it is called a long onion, naganegi or just negi. To an American, it looks like a scallion that is ready to play in the N.B.A. It is nearly two feet long and is actually an Asian leek (Allium ramosum). Only the white part is used, and when eaten raw, it has a mild scallion flavor. Because it is thicker than a scallion, it is excellent to marinate and grill, to cut thin on the bias for a salad, to poach lightly and then bathe in a vinaigrette or to bake au gratin.

headline.main: Big Apple, Meet Japan's Big Onion

docs.snippet: This pastry chef makes house calls. Michel Floranc, above, who owns Toute Sweet, a wholesale pastry kitchen in Woodside, Queens, will bake souffles or molten chocolate cakes in your kitchen for a dinner party, or he will be there simply to put his...
docs.abstract: Pastry chef Michel Florance, who owns wholesale pastry kitchen in Woodside, Queens, will bake souffles or molten chocolate cakes in your kitchen for a dinner party; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: This pastry chef makes house calls. Michel Floranc, above, who owns Toute Sweet, a wholesale pastry kitchen in Woodside, Queens, will bake souffles or molten chocolate cakes in your kitchen for a dinner party, or he will be there simply to put his desserts on plates with his own personal touch. In his repertory are excellent thin-crusted apple galettes seasoned with a whiff of cinnamon and decorated with a tangle of dried apple peel (left); sumptuous little chestnut cakes; classics like eclairs; and cakes for special occasions. Desserts prepared and put on plates in your home start at $8 a portion (no minimum number of guests), plus a charge of $25 an hour for the chef. Without Mr. Floranc's participation, the pastries start at $1.50 each for miniature tartlets and eclairs. Apple galettes are $7 each, and most large tarts and cakes, which serve 6 to 12, are $25 to $45. Delivery is available in Manhattan for orders of at least $40; (718) 429-8714.

headline.main: The Pastry Chef Who Came to Dinner

docs.snippet: Bakeries known for their bread are sidling into the cake business. Ecce Panis began making old-fashioned triple-layer cakes with chocolate and vanilla butter cream, $30 each, a few months ago. Now Amy's Bread, 672 Ninth Avenue (46th Street), is ba...
docs.abstract: Amy's Bread, New York City, has begun selling cakes by slice; photo (Food Stuff column) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Bakeries known for their bread are sidling into the cake business. Ecce Panis began making old-fashioned triple-layer cakes with chocolate and vanilla butter cream, $30 each, a few months ago. Now Amy's Bread, 672 Ninth Avenue (46th Street), is baking layer cakes that would win prizes at any county fair.

headline.main: A Slice Is Only $4, But That's Without Milk

docs.snippet: A new panettone is made with Italian olive oil from a company that encourages the public to “adopt” an olive tree....
docs.abstract: Italian pastry company Scarpato introduces holiday version of panettone made with organic olive oil from Nudo, organization that encourages the public to adopt an olive tree. Photo (S)
docs.news_desk: Dining In, Dining Out / Style Desk
docs.lead_paragraph: Panettone, the yeasty, lightly sweetened mound with a smattering of dried fruits, usually has a shelf life surpassed only by that of fruitcake. But here is a panettone that will be reduced to crumbs in a short time. Scarpato, a pastry company founded in Legnano, Italy, in 1888, is baking a not-so-traditional Christmas version, using organic olive oil in the dough. The result -- moist, rich and aromatic -- is excellent plain with a glass of sweet wine after dinner, or turned into French toast for breakfast. The olive oil comes from a company called Nudo, which supports a collection of small growers in Central Italy, and encourages the public to ''adopt'' an olive tree to help the farmers -- in return for tins of oil. Nudo Panettone, $25 plus shipping for 35.27 ounces, must be ordered by Dec. 19 for delivery before Christmas, from nudo-italia.com; if any are available after that date, they can be ordered for later delivery. Tins of olive oils start at $7.99 for 8.4 ounces. It costs $109 to adopt a tree; donors will receive two shipments of oil during the year.

headline.main: Save a Tree, Eat a Panettone

docs.snippet: Nicky Dawda rented a nice storefront in Greenwich Village, planning to do some renovations and open a tearoom with the tea expert Kiley Holliday. Simple enough? That was 18 months ago. Now after dealing with city codes, their tearoom, Bosie Tea Pa...
docs.abstract: Bosie Tea Parlor in Greenwich Village opens featuring fine teas and pastries; photo (M)
docs.news_desk: Dining In, Dining Out / Style Desk
docs.lead_paragraph: Nicky Dawda rented a nice storefront in Greenwich Village, planning to do some renovations and open a tearoom with the tea expert Kiley Holliday. Simple enough? That was 18 months ago. Now after dealing with city codes, their tearoom, Bosie Tea Parlor, will open on Thursday with about 100 of Ms. Holliday's hand-selected L'Age de The teas in golden canisters on the shelves. She also brews a mighty fine cup. To accompany the teas in the cafe area, in the dark wood bar or to take home, are exquisite pastries made by Damien Herrgott, who worked at Laduree in Paris and Bouley Bakery in New York. And, with some extra time to tweak his restaurant, Mr. Dawda has hired Chris Siversen, the chef and an owner of Maritime Parc in Liberty State Park in New Jersey, as a consultant to work with Mr. Herrgott on the savory side of the menu.

headline.main: A New Spot in the Village For a Tea Break
